results.title: Love me tender
results.creator_credit: David Weisbart, Robert D Webb and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Love Me Tender is most noteable for being Elvis Presley’s cinematic debut and the launching pad for one of his most recognisable hits Love Me Tender. The story of the Reno brothers starts at the end of the Civil War. Presley is Clint Reno a young farmer trying to keep the family farm running after the family are told that the oldest brother, Vance Reno has been killed in battle. Believing his brother is dead, Clint and Vance’s sweetheart Kathy marry. However, Vance returns with the intention of marrying Kathy. Clint receives reassurance from Vance that he bears no resentment towards the pair. However, the trios relationships with one another are soon tested when Vance is arrested and taken away for trial. This one event leads the trio to a climatic encounter that ends tragicly for all. While in the majority of the film Presley gets to display his acting ability the story is broken up with Presley singing and dancing.

results.title: Love me or leave me
results.creator_credit: Joe Pasternak, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Charles Vidor
results.brief_description: Show-casing her dramatic capabilities, Doris Day gives a surprising performance as the 1930’s torch singer Ruth Etting. Etting’s big break came when she was discovered by Chicago gangster Martin, “The Gimp” Snyder. Using the ruthless methods that he is accustomed to, the Gimp fulfills Ruth’s ambitions by providing her with material riches and renown on stage and screen. He also provides her with his hand in marriage. She pays a high cost personally however, living in an atmosphere of violence and fear that worsens when Martin discovers that Ruth has fallen in love with musician Johnny Alderman (Cameron Mitchell). Nominated for 6 Academy Awards, “Love me or leave me” is a departure from traditional musicals as it focuses on the trials and tribulations of love, fear and tragedy in relationships, played out against a backdrop of songs such as “Mean to me”, “Ten cents a dance” and “I’ll never stop loving you”. Cast also includes Robert Keith and Tom Tully.

results.title: Love Letters from Teralba Road
results.creator_credit: Richard Brennan, Australian Film Commission and Stephen Wallace
results.brief_description: This excellent film was one of the first significant films of the revived Australian film industry to focus on working-class characters. It has a raw, painful and moving story, based on real love letters uncovered in a flat in Newcastle by director Stephen Wallace, and the first impressive screen performance from a young Bryan Brown. Cast also includes Kris McQuade, Gia Carides, Joy Hruby, Kevin Leslie, Ashe Venn. Photography by Tom Cowan, assistant photography by Martha Ansara.

results.title: Love lessons = Lust och Fagring Stor
results.creator_credit: Per Holst, Danske Filminstitut, Nordisk Films Kompagni, Svenska filminstitutet and Bo Widerberg
results.brief_description: Set in 1943 in Malmo (Sweden) ‘Love Lessons’ follows the sexual awakening of Stig (Johan Widerberg, the director’s son), a 15 year old student, with his teacher Viola (Marika Lagercrantz), 22 year his senior. At the beginning of the school year Stig is just one more adolescent, as ignorant as he is curious about women and sex. He develops an immediate crush on his new teacher, Viola, who is unhappily married to an alcoholic travelling salesman. Breaking every ethical code, Viola spends every afternoon giving Stig love lessons, until the day the young man meets Viola’s husband and becomes sympathetic to his plight. Sharing his time between a demanding lover and an unexpected friend, Stig’s life becomes even more complex when the young girl living next door directs her affection towards him. Feeling Stig’s love waning, Viola extracts a petty revenge on him, perhaps teaching the young man the ultimate love lesson: “hell hath no fury like a woman’s scorn”. Winner of the Silver Bear award at the Berlin Film Festival 1995. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.title: Love laughs at Andy Hardy
results.creator_credit: Robert Sisk, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Willis Goldbeck
results.brief_description: This post-WWII film of the Hardy family reflects the true-life situation of Mickey Rooney as he plays G.I. Andy Hardy returning from his tour of duty at the war. The Hardy family represents the “typcial” stereotype American family with Andy a typical American teenager, interested in cars and girls, his stern but understanding father Judge James Hardy (Lewis Stone) and his dear loving mother Mrs Hardy (Fay Holden). When Andy finds himself falling for the lovely college co-ed Kay Wilson (Bonita Granville), little does he realise what disappointments lay ahead. Delightful, light-hearted romantic comedy based on the characters created by Aurania Rouverol. Cast also includes Sara Haden, Lina Romay and Dorothy Ford.

results.title: Love is the devil: study for a portrait of Francis Bacon
results.creator_credit: Chiara Menage, BBC Film Unit, BFI and John Maybury
results.brief_description: Love is the Devil: A Study For A Portrait of Francis Bacon is indeed a portrait in the style of controversial British painter Bacon. Like Bacon’s confronting yet compelling portraits, John Maybury’s film intensely focuses on its subject - revelling in distortion and pain. The film follows the turbulent, sado-masochistic relationship Bacon (Derek Jacobi) had with George Dwyer (Daniel Craig), who he meets when he accidently stumbles upon Dwyer attempting to burgle Bacon’s meagre apartment. Francis simply says to George: “Take off your clothes. Come to bed and you can have whatever you want”. The relationship has a destructive effect on the passive George who feels uncomfortable with Bacon’s eccentric friends (Tilda Swinton is especially creepy as one of this coterie), and who is continually tortured by Bacon’s sadistic enjoyment of pain and suffering. Derek Jacobi and Daniel Craig are excellent as the two main characters.

results.title: Love is in the air. Eps. 4 & 5
results.creator_credit: Tony Wyzenbeek, Richard Stomps, Paul Clarke and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Love is in the air”.
Episode three of “Love is in the air” looks at the imprecise science of success in the pop music business. A large focus is on Kylie Mingoue, a phenomenally successful pop artist who has reinvented herself numerous times through her stellar career. Other artists such as Todd Hunter (from “Dragon”) talk about the self-destructive streak within the band that sabotaged potential worldwide success; a sentiment echoed by James Freud from “The Models”. Another artist examined in John Farnham, whose early success meant he was poison to radio stations for a time, but whose music won out through the persistence of his manager Glenn Wheatly. Also examines the succes of bands “Air supply”, “Crowded house” and “Savage garden”. Interviewees include Michael Gudinski, Glenn Wheatly, Nick Seymour, Darren Hayes and Kylie. Episode 4 (final) celebrates some of the greatest Australian songs and their writers, the stories behind which illustrate the ephemeral nature of pop songwriting. Interviewees include: James Reyne, Mark Seymour, Neil Finn, Richard Clapton and John Paul Young. An interesting and illuminating series.
